DOCNAME: CASE OF TIMES NEWSPAPERS LTD v. THE UNITED KINGDOM (Nos. 1 AND 2)
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Simon Brown
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , ORG , is the proprietor and publisher of The ORG newspaper . The applicant is registered in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE The ORG published an article in the printed version of the newspaper headlined “ Second NORP Link to Money Laundering ” . This article stated :
“ NORP and NORP investigators are examining the role of an alleged second NORP mafia boss over possible involvement in money - laundering through ORG .

Investigators are understood to be looking at links to [ PERSON : his name was set out in full in the original article ] , whose company , ORG , has been described by the ORG as an ‘ organisation associated with NORP criminal activity’ .
[ PERSON ] ’s name surfaced in earlier money - laundering investigations which may have links to ORG affair , in which MONEY of NORP money are alleged to have been laundered .

The NORP - born businessman came to the attention of NORP and NORP investigators in DATE . They suspected ORG of using its former international base in GPE as a front for a large - scale money - laundering operation . His name also figured in a NORP police report in DATE , known as GPE , which looked at the extent of the influence of the NORP mob in GPE .
[ PERSON ] has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing or links to criminal activity .

ORG , which has since moved out of GPE , is also alleged to have been involved in the smuggling of nuclear weapons and by DATE reportedly controlled CARDINAL businesses in the former GPE and another CARDINAL companies in the LOC .
The ORG has learnt that these included DATE CARDINAL offshore companies in NORP jurisdictions , including LOC and LOC .
They were administered through a chartered accountant in central GPE whose offices and home were raided in DATE by officers from GPE .
The companies were suspected of being used to help launder money from GPE , which was then channelled through NORP banks . No charges were ever filed against the accountant .
At about the same time a NORP associate said to have been a frontman for [ PERSON ] was stopped and questioned after arriving at a GPE airport . No charges were filed against him .

The NORP investigation into ORG is believed to have failed because of the difficulty of establishing that the money funnelled through offshore companies controlled by ORG was linked to criminal activities .

[ PERSON ] is alleged to be a former business associate of PERSON , the former NORP Prime Minister , and in DATE his name hit the headlines after it emerged that he had been photographed with President PERSON at a NORP fund - raising event in DATE .
He is also alleged to have had business dealings with ORG , the NORP - based mafia figure at the centre of ORG investigation . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE The ORG published a second article entitled “ ORG to ORG , Wife Claims ” . This article stated :
“ A NORP businessman under investigation by NORP authorities pursuing allegations of money - laundering was a friend of [ GPE ] , a suspected mafia boss , the businessman ’s wife claims .
ORG , the aluminium magnate under NORP investigation , was given access to staff and a chauffeur by [ GPE ] when he moved to GPE , according to ORG , Mr Chernoi ’s estranged wife ...

If PERSON allegation about a connection between her husband and [ PERSON ] is true , it will raise further questions about Mr Chernoi . In DATE the ORG described ORG , a company operated by [ GPE ] and alleged to have been used to launder money and smuggle nuclear weapons , as an ‘ organisation associated with NORP criminal activity’ .
In DATE [ PERSON ] triggered a row in GPE after a photograph was published of him with President PERSON in DATE . [ PERSON ] has denied any wrongdoing . ”
CARDINAL . Both articles were uploaded onto the applicant ’s website on DATE as they were published in its newspaper .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON brought proceedings for libel in respect of the CARDINAL articles printed in the newspaper against the applicant , its editor and the CARDINAL journalists under whose bylines the articles appeared ( “ the first action ” ) . The defendants did not dispute that the articles were potentially defamatory and did not seek to prove that the allegations were true . Instead , they relied solely on the defence of qualified privilege , contending that the allegations were of such a kind and seriousness that they had a duty to publish the information and the public had a corresponding right to know .

CARDINAL . While the first action was under way , the articles remained on the applicant ’s website , where they were accessible to Internet users as part of the applicant ’s archive of past issues . On DATE , PERSON brought a second action for libel in relation to the continuing Internet publication of the articles ( “ the second action ” ) . Initially , the GPE only defence to the second action was CARDINAL of qualified privilege . The CARDINAL actions were consolidated and set down for a split trial on issues of liability and then quantum .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant added the following preface to both articles in the Internet archive :
“ This article is subject to ORG libel litigation between [ PERSON ] and ORG . It should not be reproduced or relied on without reference to ORG . ”

CARDINAL . NORP In or around DATE the defendants applied to re - amend their defence in the second action in order “ to contend that as a matter of law the only actionable publication of a newspaper article on the Internet is that which occurs when the article is first posted on the Internet ” ( “ the single - publication rule ” ) . They argued that , as a result , the second action was time - barred by CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused permission to re - amend the defence , relying in particular on the common - law rule set out in Duke of GPE v. PERSON ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) that each publication of a defamation gives rise to a separate cause of action . The court held that , in the context of the Internet , this meant that a new cause of action accrued every time the defamatory material was accessed ( “ the Internet publication rule ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that the defendants had no reasonable grounds for contending that after DATE ( the date on which the defendants lodged their defence in the first action ) they remained under a duty to publish the articles on the Internet . As a result , the court struck out the defence of qualified privilege in relation to the second action . On DATE , judgment was entered for PERSON in the second action , with damages to be assessed . By this time the applicant had removed the articles from its website .

CARDINAL . The defendants appealed against ORG order of DATE rejecting the single - publication rule . They argued that the Internet publication rule breached LAW , pointing out that as a result of the rule , newspapers which maintained Internet archives were exposed to ceaseless liability for republication of the defamatory material . The defendants argued that this would inevitably have a chilling effect on the willingness of newspapers to provide Internet archives and would thus limit their freedom of expression .
CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE , ORG , per ORG , dismissed the appeal against the order in the second action , stating :

“ We do not accept that the rule in the Duke of GPE imposes a restriction on the readiness to maintain and provide access to archives that amounts to a disproportionate restriction on freedom of expression . We accept that the maintenance of archives , whether in hard copy or on the Internet , has a social utility , but consider that the maintenance of archives is a comparatively insignificant aspect of freedom of expression . Archive material is stale news and its publication can not rank in importance with the dissemination of contemporary material . Nor do we believe that the law of defamation need inhibit the responsible maintenance of archives . Where it is known that archive material is or may be defamatory , the attachment of an appropriate notice warning against treating it as the truth will normally remove any sting from the material . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused leave to appeal . The parties subsequently settled the action and the applicant agreed to pay PERSON a sum of money in full and final settlement of claims and costs arising in both actions .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) sets out a general limitation period of DATE in tort actions . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act qualifies this limitation period as regards defamation actions and provides as follows :
“ The time - limit under LAW shall not apply to an action for DATE
( a ) NORP libel or slander ; or
( b ) slander of title , slander of goods or other malicious falsehood ;
but no such action shall be brought after the expiration of DATE from the date on which the cause of action accrued . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINALA of the DATE Act provides :
“ ( CARDINAL ) It if appears to the court that it would be equitable to allow an action to proceed having regard to the degree to which –
( a ) the operation of section CARDINAL of this Act prejudices the plaintiff or any person whom he represents ; and
( b ) any decision of the court under this subsection would prejudice the defendant or any person whom he represents ;
the court may direct that that section shall not apply to the action or shall not apply to any specified cause of action to which the action relates .

( b ) where the reason or one of the reasons for the delay was that all or any of the facts relevant to the cause of action did not become known to the plaintiff until after the end of the period mentioned in section DATE

CARDINAL . Duke of GPE v. PERSON [ DATE ] CARDINAL QB CARDINAL lays down a common - law rule of some significance . On DATE an article was published in ORG . The limitation period for libel was , at that time , DATE . The article defamed the Duke of GPE . DATE after its publication an agent of the ORG purchased a back number containing the article from ORG office . Another copy was obtained from ORG . The ORG sued on those CARDINAL publications . The defendant contended that the cause of action was time - barred , relying on the original publication date . The court held that the delivery of a copy of the newspaper to the plaintiff ’s agent constituted a separate publication in respect of which suit could be brought .

CARDINAL . In PERSON v. ORG [ DATE ] ORG the respondent brought an action in defamation against the appellants who were Internet service providers . They had received and stored on their news server an article , defamatory of the respondent , which had been posted by an unknown person using another service provider . The judge stated :

“ In my judgment the defendants , whenever they transmit and whenever there is transmitted from the storage of their news server a defamatory posting , publish that posting to any subscriber to their ORG [ Internet service provider ] who accesses the newsgroup containing that posting . Thus every time CARDINAL of the defendants’ customers accesses ‘ soc culture thai’ and sees that posting defamatory of the plaintiff there is a publication to that customer . ”

CARDINAL . The leading case on the defence of qualified privilege is ORG [ DATE ] CARDINAL AC CARDINAL . That case established that qualified privilege is an absolute defence to libel proceedings . In the leading judgment before ORG , Lord PERSON of GPE explained the defence as follows :

“ The underlying principle is conventionally stated in words to the effect that there must exist between the maker of the statement and the recipient some duty or interest in the making of the communication . Lord PERSON ’s dictum , in PERSON [ DATE ] A.C. CARDINAL , CARDINAL , is much quoted :

‘ a privileged occasion is ... an occasion where the person who makes a communication has an interest or a duty , legal , social , or moral , to make it to the person to whom it is made , and the person to whom it is so made has a corresponding interest or duty to receive it . This reciprocity is essential’ . ”
CARDINAL . ORG has adopted a Code of Practice which is regularly reviewed and amended as required . Paragraph CARDINAL of the current Code of Practice reads as follows :
“ ( i ) The Press must take care not to publish inaccurate , misleading or distorted information , including pictures .
( ii ) A significant inaccuracy , misleading statement or distortion once recognised must be corrected , promptly and with due prominence , and – where appropriate DATE an apology published .
( iii ) The Press , whilst free to be partisan , must distinguish clearly between comment , conjecture and fact .

( iv ) A publication must report fairly and accurately the outcome of an action for defamation to which it has been a party , unless an agreed settlement states otherwise , or an agreed statement is published . ”

CARDINAL . Unlike GPE , the courts of GPE have chosen to apply the “ single - publication rule ” . In the case of PERSON v. ORG Sons ( DATE ) CARDINAL ORG , a book originally put on sale in DATE was still being sold in DATE following several reprints . ORG considered the rule in Duke of GPE v. PERSON , but concluded that it was formulated “ in an era which long antedated the modern process of mass publication ” and was therefore not suited to modern conditions . Instead , the court held that the limitation period started to run in DATE , when the book was first put on sale . The court pointed out that :

“ Under [ the rule in Duke of GPE v. PERSON ] LAW would never expire so long as a copy of such book remained in stock and is made by the publisher the subject of a sale or inspection by the public . Such a rule would thwart the purpose of the legislature . ”

CARDINAL . The single - publication rule was subsequently applied to a website publication in GPE of GPE DATE ) NY int CARDINAL . In that case , a report published at a press conference on DATE was placed on the Internet DATE . An action was brought over DATE . ORG held that the limitation period started when the report was first uploaded onto the website and did not begin anew each time the website version of the report was accessed by a user . The court observed that :

“ The policies impelling the original adoption of the single - publication rule support its application to the posting of ... the report ... on the website ... These policies are even more cogent when considered in connection with the exponential growth of the instantaneous , worldwide ability to communicate through the Internet ... Thus a multiple publication rule would implicate an even greater potential for endless retriggering of the statute of limitations , multiplicity of suits and harassment of defendants . Inevitably , there would be a serious inhibitory effect on the open , pervasive dissemination of information and ideas over the Internet which is , of course , its greatest beneficial promise . ”
